abstractContent.text: The paradigm of parsing as intersection has been used throughout the literature to obtain elegant and general solutions to numerous problems involving grammars and automata.
The paradigm has its origins in (Bar-Hillel et al., 1964), where a general construction was used to prove closure of context-free languages under intersection with regular languages.
It was pointed out by (Lang, 1994) that such a construction isolates the parsing problem from the recognition problem.
The latter can be solved by a reduction of the outcome of intersection.
